ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

BILL SIZES IN DIFFERENT CLASSES OF WARDS

     1.  Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Minister of Health for 2009, what is (i) the average bill incurred by patients in the A, B1, B2 and C wards respectively; (ii) the distribution of patients over the different classes of wards; (iii) the amount of out-of-pocket expenses incurred by patients in the different classes; and (iv) the increase in bill sizes from 2008.

     The Minister for Health (Mr Khaw Boon Wan):  I do not have the complete 2009 data yet.  Based on the claims submitted during the first nine months of 2009, the average acute hospital bills incurred in Class A, B1, B2 and C wards were respectively: $4,751; $3,873; $1,660; and $1,506.

 

     The distribution of patients was 8% in Class A, 12% in B1, 39% in B2 and 41% in C.

 

     Patients would tap on various kinds of payment modes, from Medisave, insurance, employers’ medical benefits to outright cash.  I do not have the breakdown of these payment modes. 

Column: 2602

However, we know that 80% of all subsidised patients would not need to fork out any cash, after Medisave and MediShield deductions.   

    

     Between 2008 and 2009, the increase in the average bill sizes ranged from 3% in Class B1 to 10% in Class B2.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong):  Mr Speaker, Sir, I have two questions to ask the Minister.  My first question is this.  In most countries, the most significant impact on people's ability to pay for their medical bills is the out-of-pocket expenses.  The Minister said that only 20% need to pay cash – what is the Minister's sense of whether this will increase in future, and whether this out-of-pocket component will have an impact on affordability, particularly now that the population is ageing and people have less income after retirement.  Of course, we need to be concerned about those who are not working – the women who are staying at home.

 

     My second question is to ask the Minister whether the increase in bills, particularly for the lower-end wards, is something that is reasonable and would still make staying in hospitals affordable.

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  Indeed, affordability has to do with ability to pay.  In our case, quite unique in the world, we have a compulsory savings scheme through Medisave.  Without Medisave, healthcare costs would be quite difficult to afford.  I think this is one advantage that we have built up over more than 24 years now.  And it is an advantage that will continue to be beneficial to Singaporeans.


     As I said earlier, with Medisave and MediShield, 80% need not have to come out with a single dollar.  The other 20% of patients have to come out with some money but it has not been a major issue.  That has been our experience in the hospitals.  One evidence is the extent of

Column: 2603

bad debt.  In many countries, hospital bad debt is a problem.  That is an expression of unaffordability, where they are not able to pay and therefore ending up with an inability to pay their bills.  But in our public hospitals, bad debt has not been a problem.  The last I saw, bad debt was about 2% of total revenue, which is quite reasonable.

 

     I gave a range of increases in bills – from 3% in Class B1 to 10% in Class B2.  The other classes are in between.  Class A is 7% and Class C is 8%.  The reasons for cost increases have been discussed several times in this House.  Wage increase is one because this is a very labour-intensive industry.  Some of the cost increases are deliberate because as I explained to this House in 2007, we wanted to improve the staff-to-patient ratio.  We launched a five-year programme in 2007 to increase doctors, nurses and allied professionals substantially.  Next week, when we discuss our Ministry's budget, I will give an update on the progress of this significant increase in staffing level.  That was a deliberate move and would push up costs.  But as I promised when we launched that programme three years ago, the bulk of the cost increases will be borne by the Government because our subsidy policy remains unchanged.

     Dr Lam Pin Min (Ang Mo Kio):  Thank you, Sir.  I have two supplementary questions.  One is with regard to the utilisation of the different classes of wards.  Does the Minister think there is any shift in the utilisation of the different classes after the implementation of means testing?  Are we pushing Singaporeans to use Class B2 and C wards, rather than Class B1 and A because of the decreased subsidies?  Secondly, with regard to the bad debt issue, is there a mechanism whereby the hospitals can advise Singaporeans, especially those from the low to middle-income groups, not to opt for the higher classes of wards because,

Column: 2604

at the end of the day, the bill may be quite substantial?

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  Bed occupancy for the different classes of wards does differ.  I do not have the figures off hand.  In subsidised wards, it is higher. The shift is noticeable in one aspect – when patients know that their illnesses are complex, they would generally ask to be downgraded to Class C or B2 as they know they may end up in ICU and Class A charges in ICU can be very expensive. We would do some means testing and where they are obviously in financial difficulty, we will allow the downgrading.  That is why the length of stay in Class C is the longest compared to Class A.  Those who have minor ailments – likely three or four days in hospital and generally with MediShield and Medisave, they can afford it – they will opt for a private ward.  I think this is rational behaviour.  The question is whether there was a shift with means testing.  If there was, it was not noticeable.  We expected that with means testing, only about 10% of the higher-income group would be in Class C or B2, and that has been our experience so far.  By and large, Singaporeans are choosing their wards according to their means, which is good.  Those who can afford it and do not require as much subsidy, go to the higher classes of wards, and those who cannot afford it, go to the Class C wards.  This is the principle behind means testing.  The short answer is, "so far, so good". 


     As to advising patients on choice of ward, we do that systematically.  At admission, every patient would be given financial counselling. By that time, we would know the preliminary diagnosis and from experience, we could estimate the likely length of stay for a patient with such an aliment, and the cost of the stay.  With computers, we are able to churn out the data and present to family members the estimated bill size for a stay in Class B1, B2, C wards. And they make the

Column: 2605

choice.  I think that is a good approach which we have been able to refine as we go along.

WAITING TIME FOR BEDS IN PUBLIC HOSPITALS

     2.  Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Minister for Health (a) what is the average waiting time for beds in the public hospitals for both emergency and non-emergency cases; (b) what measures are being taken to address the problem of bed shortage; and (c) whether the bed crunch in public hospitals has affected the quality of care for patients.

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  Sir, our Emergency Departments attend to all life-threatening cases immediately.  There is no waiting for such patients.

 

     For non-emergency cases which require admission, their waiting time for a bed will depend on the hospital they visit.  Overall, we have sufficient beds but there are mismatches on certain days, like Mondays and Tuesdays, resulting in some patients having to wait for a bed longer than we desire.  I can explain why if you ask me a supplementary question later on.

 

     To address the problem, we have added new hospital beds over the years, while building the new Khoo Teck Puat Hospital and planning the new Jurong General Hospital.   This has provided some relief.

 

     This January, for example, the average bed occupancy rate was 82%, ranging from 74% at Alexandra Hospital, 81% at Singapore General Hospital to 89% at Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH).  The average bed occupancy rate went down to 77% in February as patients avoided hospitalisation during the Lunar New Year.  With the end of the festivity,

Column: 2606

elective admissions have returned.  So last week we were heavily stressed.

 

     Among the hospitals, TTSH has the highest number of admissions from its Emergency Department.  This is because it serves a large population catchment, both from the north and the central part of Singapore.
  
     Nonetheless, most patients do not have to wait long.  At TTSH, half of the emergency department admissions in January were admitted to their assigned wards within two hours.  Another 35% of patients waited two to four hours.  But 5% of patients had to wait more than eight hours.

 

     In order to relieve the overcrowding in TTSH, the other hospitals have chipped in, to handle the overflows of ambulance cases and admissions.  This has, in turn, spread the problem to them, especially to CGH which had a bed occupancy rate of 91% last week.  So we are all eagerly awaiting the opening of the Khoo Teck Puat Hospital later this year.  That will add 555 beds to our capacity.

 

     The shortage of beds on certain days of the week has a significant impact on customer service.  Patients, naturally, would like to be admitted to and be able to get settled down in their preferred ward immediately.  Our failure to do so for some patients who have to wait a few hours for this to happen is unsatisfactory.  I am sorry for this lapse in service level.

 

     However, the clinical care for such patients is never compromised.  When patients are waiting to be admitted, they continue to receive the appropriate care.  Their doctors would assess the patients, order the necessary tests and initiate the appropriate treatment immediately.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob:  Sir, supplementary questions.  Of course, since the Minister has indicated I should ask the

Column: 2607

question, my first question is why is there a problem on Mondays and Tuesdays.  The second question is related to the perception on the ground that seems quite prevalent, that foreigners are depriving Singaporeans of beds and are crowding them out.  Is this a true perception, particularly in the subsidised wards?

 

 


     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:   In hospitals, we handle both, what we call electives – non-emergencies and of course emergencies.  Public hospitals typically handle a huge share of emergency workload because we are the only ones with true emergency departments.  Private hospitals generally handle elective cases.  Elective cases have the advantage of predictability; you plan for it.  So if you need something, it can be done this week or next week or next month – it does not really matter.  Your health is not affected by it, and you can choose the date.  Of course, hospitals and doctors prefer electives because life is simpler, whereas emergencies are so unpredictable.  In public hospitals, all emergency workloads are heavy.  But some hospitals have heavy electives, too.  SGH, for example.  Of all the admissions into SGH, I would say about 40% to 45% are electives and 55% are emergencies.  Whereas other hospitals like Tan Tock Seng or Changi, the emergency workload is about 90%, so electives make up less than 10%.  As electives are scheduled events, doctors generally make the request for the hospitals to schedule elective admissions on Sunday so that the surgery can be done on Monday or Tuesday.  The emergency work is still there, but on Mondays and Tuesdays, we superimpose the electives on the emergency workload.  That is why Mondays and Tuesdays become extra heavy days.  And because patients stay a few days, it all accumulates.  So for subsequent days of the week, we will cut down the elective numbers in order to accommodate the number of patients in our available beds.  That explains this peak pattern on Mondays and Tuesdays.


    

Column: 2608

Over the years, we try to manage but the bottomline is, yes, we are at the moment a bit short of beds.  And the correct solution is to delay electives.  In fact, in many countries electives take months.  But we have been spoilt to be able to respond to electives within a few weeks.  When my visitors come in from Europe or US, they express surprise.  They said, "why do you do that?".  For them, to wait a few months for elective surgery is no big deal.  But because we have now reached this standard, it is very hard to reduce it.  So I plead for some patience, if we have to delay the electives a little in order to cope with this immediate shortage of beds for the next few months, until we fully open Khoo Teck Puat Hospital.


     Do foreigners crowd out locals?  The statistics do not show that because we know that foreigners, including PRs, make up maybe one-third or 35% of the total resident population here.  But in subsidised wards, they only make up about 15% of the total in-patient load.  85% are Singaporeans.  Why foreigners make up 35% of the population but 15% of in-patient load can be explained because the foreigners, the people working here, are generally young, as compared to locals staying here.  Older people do get hospitalised more often.

Column: 2608

FUNDING OF MALAY AND TAMIL TV PROGRAMMES

(Period of review)

     3.  Mr Zaqy Mohamad asked the Acting Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts (a) how often the Media Development Authority (MDA) reviews the funding for public broadcasting of Malay and Tamil programmes; (b) when was the last time the funding was reviewed for both types of programmes and what was the increase in funding to improve the quality of programmes by MediaCorp; and (c) compared to the

Column: 2609

English and Mandarin channels, what is the proportion of re-run programmes on the Malay and Tamil channels during prime time and off-peak periods.  

      The Acting Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts (RAdm [NS] Lui Tuck Yew):   Sir, Suria and Vasantham are important channels that reflect our multi-cultural heritage and multi-racial society.  They offer relevant Malay and Tamil programmes for these two communities. To support these two channels, the Media Development Authority (MDA) provides public service broadcast (PSB) funding for the production and acquisition of quality programmes, such as news, current affairs, drama and children's programmes.

 

     Together with MediaCorp, MDA carries out annual reviews of the funding for PSB programmes across all MediaCorp's TV channels.   These annual reviews ensure that the programmes continue to be of high standards and of relevance to Singaporeans.

 

     MDA also conducts periodic studies to assess the state of MediaCorp's TV channels.  The launch of Vasantham as a standalone channel in 2008 was a recommendation of such a study.  As a result, Vasantham's local programme hours have more than doubled from 30 hours to 65 hours a week, and the channel also offers a wider variety of Tamil programmes.

 

     To provide greater support for quality local Malay and Tamil programmes, MDA has increased 2010 PSB funding for Suria and Vasantham by about 12% and 27% respectively compared to two years ago, ie, FY2008.  Besides supporting MediaCorp's launch of Vasantham as a full-fledged channel, the increase in funding had improved the quality and diversity of

Column: 2610

programmes for both channels, and reduced the repeat rates. 

 

     On repeat rates during prime time and off prime time, these vary across MediaCorp's channels depending on the strategy adopted for each channel. For repeat rates during prime time, Vasantham's  is now at a level comparable to that for Channel 8.  For Suria, whilst the repeat rate is higher, it is comparable to Channel 5 and CNA. 

 

     Ultimately, the true test is whether the viewership for Suria and Vasantham has improved.  On this count, both Suria and Vasantham have done well, increasing their viewership over the past few years.  In 2007, Suria's viewership averaged about 40,000 Malay viewers during prime time; this has increased by more than 65% to about 67,000 viewers last year.  Over the same period, Vasantham's prime time viewership, which averaged about 24,000 Indian viewers before its launch as a standalone channel, has increased by about 50% to 36,000 viewers currently.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to assure the House that MDA will continue to review its funding support for PSB programmes on Suria and Vasantham, as well as the rest of MediaCorp's channels, so that Singaporeans have every opportunity to enjoy a wide variety of high quality local programmes.

 

     Mr Zaqy Mohamad (Hong Kah):  Mr Speaker, I thank the Minister for his clarification as well as the increased funding for the FY2010 budget.  I just want to check with the Minister – with increased funding, does MDA also monitor the quality of current affairs programmes to support public communication as well as Government communication?  The two channels face increasing pressure from the cable TV providers to go into entertainment but I think there is also a role where we provide public service broadcast funding to ensure more current

Column: 2611

affairs programmes and Government communications.

     RAdm [NS] Lui Tuck Yew:   Indeed the funding goes largely towards supporting quality programmes in the areas of news, current affairs, children's education programmes and so on.  We have a panel comprising a good mix of members of the public, both from the professional as well as the non-professional sectors to help us, basically evaluate the quality of the programmes to take into account feedback from the public and to help us do the assessment of whether the range, the mix and the quality of the programmes are appropriate.

Column: 2611

CONTINUING EDUCATION AND TRAINING CENTRES FOR THE DISABLED

     4.  Ms Denise Phua Lay Peng asked the Minister for Manpower if he has plans to set up Continuing Education and Training centres for the disabled since similar efforts were already made for non-disabled Singaporeans. 

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Manpower (Mr Hawazi Daipi) (for the Minister for Manpower):  Mr Speaker, for CET centres to be relevant to industry needs, they are set up to deliver skills training for specific industries and occupations.  This allows CET centres to build up sector-specific training capabilities and linkages with their industries. Therefore, CET centres are not organised based on specific target groups within the labour force. 

 

     At present, the courses provided by the CET centres and other WDA Approved Training Organisations (ATOs) are open to all individuals who wish to undergo training, whether able-bodied or disabled.  As Persons with Disabilities (PWDs) may face different challenges depending on the nature of their disability, training may need to be customised for each group of PWDs.  We should tap on the expertise of the various Voluntary Welfare Organisa

Column: 2612

tions (VWOs) which are in a better position to understand the needs of the PWDs that they serve and provide customised assistance for them.

 

     A good example of how this works is the Infocomm Technology Apprenticeship Training Programme launched in July 2008. This was supported by the Info-comm Development Authority (IDA) and the Society for the Physically Disabled (SPD).  It aims to train some 4,000 persons with disabilities over the next three years.

 

     Apart from training, support for job placements and after-placement support is just as important. Currently, WDA funds the Open Door Fund, set up by MCYS, which supports companies in their effort to employ PWDs.  Apart from funding job redesign, workplace modification and integration programmes, the scheme also grants apprenticeship funding to companies providing job-specific company training for the PWDs to enable them to perform effectively at the workplace.   To date, more than 290 PWDs have been placed through the Open Door Fund.  Out of these, more than 170 PWDs were retained for at least three months.

 

     Mr Speaker:  Yes, Ms Phua, keep your question short please.

     Ms Denise Phua Lay Peng (Jalan Besar):   Sir, it seems to me that much more is done by the Government and the NTUC for the pregnant women, the married women,  the elderly,  the PMETs, and so forth – and many of whom are able-bodied.  The disabled actually need more support than just throwing them some funds.  I just conducted a three-hour visit to the KFC call centre this morning.  And I think they would benefit from some help from Government and NTUC especially if some more support and eye-balling of this group are provided; they being also the sons and daughters of Singapore although they are not able-bodied.

Column: 2613

     Mr Hawazi Daipi:  Sir, we have to identify the needs of the different types of disabled people.  And we have set up committees and organisations to help them.  For example, there is a Standing Committee on disability comprising very senior officials of the Government, Ministries and agencies.  Among other things, they have identified jobs that may be suitable for the PWDs, for example, in the F&B sector.

 

     The hearing impaired, intellectually disabled and people with autism may be suitable to be trained.  But training for them need not necessarily be centralised at a specific centre.  What we need to do and will continue to do is to work with agencies and organisations that can help people with specific disabilities so that they can be trained for specific jobs in certain industries or occupations.  And that is why we need to work with agencies, organisations including VWOs and not just focus on funding their training. So I agree with Ms Phua that we need to help them and I can assure her that we have set up the organisations and gathered concerned individuals and companies that are interested in helping them.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT

 

    Order read for resumption of Debate on Question [22nd February, 2010],

 

    "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 2010 to 31st March, 2011." – [Minister for Finance].

 

    Question again proposed.

 

12.30 pm

 

     Ms Indranee Rajah (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to participate in this Budget debate.

 

    Some have remarked that this Budget is bereft of goodies.  It is not an extravagant Budget.  That is true.  It is very much a "let's get to work" budget.  If one were to think of it in gastronomic terms, this Budget is not a chocolate dessert with whipped cream and a cherry on top. It is much more akin to a protein shake.  The former tastes wonderful but it would not make you lean and fit.  And the second does not taste as good, but it is much better for you in the long run.

 

    This Budget identifies productivity as one of the strategies for our long-term growth.  Simply put, productivity means being able to maximise the output of a particular resource in a more efficient way.  And if we want to grow as a country, then we have to be productive across all strata of our society.

 

    In this regard, I would like, in my speech, to focus on one particular group, the low income, and consider how we can help them to climb up the value chain so

Column: 2615

that they too can share in our strategy for growth.


     This ties in with that part of the Budget which deals with "Including all Singaporeans in growth".   I note the Minister's statement that we are making investments to build up a first rate system for continuing education and training with special provisions for low income Singaporeans.  I also note the Minister's statement that we are assuring every child access to the best education from pre-school to tertiary level.

 

    Whilst the Budget is well-intentioned in this regard, and has some good measures to help the low income, I think that our approach is still too broad-based, and does not address the root of the problem, which is that many of the low income are behind even before they reach the starting line of the race.

 

    Before I go on to deal with what can be done to address the problem, I would like to say a few words on the importance of having growth opportunities for all. 

 

     In this connection, I would like to reflect on the recent case of the Pasir Ris and Tampines residents who objected to rental blocks being built next to their purchased flats.  The objections included complaints like the rental flats would block their view, complaints about privacy and safety; they were afraid that rental flat neighbours would make the area unsafe and seedy and complaints that rental flats near their homes would cause the value of their properties to drop.

 

     I was dismayed when I read of these objections.

 

     It seems to me to be a fundamentally wrong approach.  One of the things we must never forget is that our vision for ourselves as a country is that we would enable all Singaporeans to progress and prosper.  Those from low income and low

Column: 2616

educational backgrounds start off at a disadvantage.  The correct approach really should be: how do we help them to level up?

 

     One of the most fundamental basic necessities that every human being needs is a home, a roof over their heads and a shelter for their families.  This gives them security and with security, the parents will then be able to focus on raising a family, and on their jobs, and the children can focus on their studies.  Rental housing is a key strategy to helping lower income Singaporeans to achieve a better life and share in Singapore's growth.  MPs, myself included, have a long time been asking for more rental housing to meet the demand.  The flats at Tampines and Pasir Ris would go a long way to help meet this demand and I was therefore saddened to learn of the reactions of some of the residents to the proposed rental flats to be built there.

 

    We should not forget that the people who need rental housing are our fellow Singaporeans.  Singapore was built on the vision that we would, as a team, achieve prosperity and progress for all.  And there is something inherently objectionable in saying that "I do not want somebody poor to live next to me because that housing for the poor will affect the value of my property".

 

     We should not have the attitude that we should not mind rental housing so long as it is not next to us.  In other words, anywhere except in our backyard.  If everyone were to adopt this attitude, then where would you put the poorer people in Singapore or house them?

 

    Surely, it is much more important to want to see our fellow Singaporeans grow and achieve a better life.

 

    It is true that those who live in rental housing tend to have more problems.  This is because  those with their income profile is such that they usually come

Column: 2617

from less educated backgrounds and this in turn means that they have less ability to get good jobs or to earn more, and they have all the attendant problems that come with lower income and lower education.

 

    Singapore has a declining birth rate. Paradoxically, lower income families tend to have larger families.  The better educated have fewer children.  This is reflective of the worldwide phenomenon where more developed societies have lower birth rates than those in less developed countries.  And the same is true at the individual level:  more affluent couples tend to have few children than lower income couples.  Our approach thus far had been to try to discourage the lower income families from having more children.  The HOPE Scheme is one such example.  A family will not qualify for financial assistance under the HOPE Scheme if they have more than two children.  The message is that you should only have more than two children if you can afford it.

 

     However, the reality is that many lower income families frequently do have more than two children.  In some of the rental flats in my constituency at Henderson Heights, there are families in 2-room rental flats who have five or six children.  That means you have seven or eight people under one roof.  I do not agree with the approach of restricting assistance just because the family has more than two children because that only serves to compound the problem.  Once born, a child cannot be unborn.  Once born, a child needs to be clothed, fed and educated.  Restricting assistance just keeps them locked in a poverty cycle.  So once a child has been brought into this world, the question is how to try and give that child, irrespective of his or her background, the best opportunity to succeed and to become a fully productive member of our society and economy. 

 

     

Column: 2618

In this regard, I actually see rental housing as an opportunity for us to develop our human resources and to help low income Singaporeans embark on the productivity train.  I see the rental flats as a catchment area of young children where we have the opportunity to do a lot of good.  Here, you have children who have potential.  Just because they are poor does not mean that they are stupid.  All it means is that you have a child with potential, but who is at a disadvantage.  The question is how you help them to overcome those disadvantages so that that potential can be realised.

 

    We all know that the answer to this is education. Whilst we have done a good job, especially with the ITEs, the reality is that many low income people still do not get the opportunity to achieve higher education and then cannot climb up the value chain, and consequently, get shut out from sharing in our growth.

 

    Why does this happen?  I have found in my rental estates that many of the parents labour under the misapprehension that it is enough to send the child to primary school and that learning and education begins in primary school.  And we know that this is not true.  Nowadays, any child who goes to primary school without adequate pre-school education or preparation ends up behind the rest of the class and it is frequently impossible for the child to catch up.  So if a child is behind in Primary 1, then what it really means, for many of them, is that that child is behind for the rest of his or her life.

 

    I have also found that for those who cannot cope, they typically tend to drop out at Secondary 2 level because this is when they hit puberty.  For girls, this is the age where some become single mothers or become pregnant.  For boys, this is when they hit their teens and become less willing to listen to adults.  They drop out of school and do not even

Column: 2619

make it to ITE.  These then land up in low skilled, low income jobs and eventually, they fall into the group who need rental housing, and the cycle begins all over again.

 

    I would like to see the Government invest more resources in breaking this cycle of poverty because the children from low income families in fact represent a great potential resource if they are properly nurtured and given the opportunity to realise their full potential.  I notice in the Budget that the Government would top up Post-Secondary Education Accounts.  However, I did not see much in relation to pre-school.  We need to do more at the pre-school and primary level because if they do not level up by Primary 6, then, in many cases, it will already be too late.

 

     I would urge the Government to consider having, within each rental housing precinct, more infant care facilities, childcare facilities, student care facilities and tuition centres.  I note that we have these facilities but right now, the infrastructure is not built such that they are altogether within a rental housing precinct.  And the problem is that when it is too far away, the low income do not have the money for transport. Sometimes, it is too far to send their children and then you have a drop-out rate.  But if you build an educational eco-system within the rental housing precinct, it makes it much easier for the parents to send their children down.  Infant care releases the mother to go to work and it allows the child to be developed at a  young age.  Student care allows the child to come back after primary school and stay there. The tuition centres help them to level up.  So if the Government could consider building an education eco-system around rental housing, I think it would go a long way towards helping this group to level up.

 

   

Column: 2620

I would also advocate that if you are going to have these childcare and student care centres, the children should be taught values, in particular, looking after their parents.  Increasingly, we are beginning to see cases where children do not look after their parents. I have a case of an old lady who came to see me for an appeal for a flat.  She said that she had had a 3-room flat.  She sold her 3-room flat and gave the sale proceeds to her daughter.  The daughter took the money and bought a 4-room flat with her husband.  However, they would not allow the old lady to stay with them because the son-in-law did not get along with the old lady.  So her daughter had no qualms about taking her mother's money – thank you very much for the money, but I am sorry that you cannot stay with me.  And that again seems to me to be fundamentally wrong.

 

    So the daughter was content to take her mother's money and have other people, the taxpayers' money, to support her mother.  These are things which you cannot really legislate upon.  If you want our children to look after their parents, it is something that needs to come from the heart.  But it is not going to come from the heart unless they are taught from a young age, that is, it is imbued in them.  And if children do not look after their parents, as our population gets older, this is going to pose more and more of a drain on our resources and future budgets.

 

    I hope that the Government would place greater emphasis on teaching and encouraging these values from children at a young age and that we would build an infrastructure where we can help the lower income to level up.  

 

    Sir, with this, I support the Budget.

Column: 2621

budget statement will give Singapore a fresh and promising start as we take the initiatives to upgrade and prepare our economy for the new decade. Column: 2622

Column: 2623

States, Australia, Japan or Thailand. The waitress anticipated the needs of her customers and attended to them even before she was asked. In that way, she kept on top of things and managed the situation very well.  I am sure many of us have also witnessed how, in Singapore, a waitress may bring a dish to the table, go back to her station empty-handed and, two minutes later, another waitress may walk empty-handed to that table to clear away a few used plates that had already been sitting around. Column: 2624

We would not have been able to bring up our five children as well as we have, especially when they were very young, and still continued to have both our careers and carry out our public and volunteer duties if we had not lived together with my parents. We are grateful to my parents who helped and still help to keep a watchful and loving eye over our children, providing them a warm, nurturing and healthy environment and passing on their time-tested values to our children. To increase our TFR, I believe we should encourage more parents to commit to help bring up their children's children.

They may have started off on a good note – a newly-married couple having their parents live with them, and also in the example cited by Ms Indranee Rajah, some parents might even have sold their old flat to live with their son or daughter in a newer or larger flat. While it is not good Government policy to provide a rental flat for all parents who want to live away from their children, and children and family members should be encouraged to take care of their elderly parents or relatives, more help should be extended to the family caregivers.

This year's Budget provides for higher relief for taxpayers living with parents, but this is useful only to those who earn enough to pay tax.  We should also extend financial help to lower-income Singaporeans who do not earn enough to have to pay tax, but live with their parents or have their parents live with them. a HDB flat from the open market, they may have to fork out $500 per month for rent. driver of growth contributing to 65% of GDP growth during that period.  We can do this again.

 

     Three decades on, productivity remains an enduring imperative.  While the objective of productivity growth is the same, the means to achieve it will change.  We are now a more developed country, further up the productivity curve.  The competitive environment has also changed.  We have made progress but those ahead of us have also progressed and moved up as well, and those behind us have made rapid advances and are catching up with us. New strategies and methods will be needed for this steeper climb.

 

     In the 1980s, the focus was on raising the basic levels of training and education to support our developing industries.  Today, we need to equip ourselves with more specialised expertise in specific fields to tap on new growth opportunities, eg, in areas like bio-medical sciences and clean technology.  Today, many countries, such as China, have mastered efficient low-cost production systems and they can do so more effectively given their scale.  Hence, it is no longer sufficient to focus on optimising or reducing production costs to improve the bottomline.  In addition, we must also look at new ways of improving the top line, looking harder at new and innovative ways of creating new products and services and going into new markets to capture greater value.

 

     At this point, it is worth clarifying what we mean by productivity as it could mean different things to different people.  Productivity is essentially a measure of how much output we can get for our inputs.  Positive productivity growth means that we are able to grow our outputs faster than we grow our inputs.  As Mr Ong Ah Heng, Mr Christopher de Souza and others mentioned, raising productivity does not necessarily mean cutting the number of workers but could

Column: 2733

also come from raising the output which I think is much better.

 

     Labour productivity is the most common measure of productivity used internationally.  But this does not also mean that the responsibility for productivity improvement lies with the worker alone.  It is not working harder or longer at the expense of families and other aspects of life, as emphasised by Mr Seng Han Thong, Ms Irene Ng, Dr Amy Khor, Assoc. Prof. Straughan, Mr Ong Kian Min and Er Lee Bee Wah.  It is also not just about automating existing processes.

 

     There are many factors working together to determine productivity.  These include the quality of the systems, processes, technology, organisation and workforce within enterprises, as Mr Christopher de Souza pointed out.  It is also about the attractiveness of the products and services to their markets, as pointed out by Mr Lim Swee Say in his usual graphic style, and moving to higher value activities.

 

     Finally, as Mr Seah Kian Peng and Ms Irene Ng stressed, leadership and management are crucial to bringing all these factors together.

 

     As Mdm Ho Geok Choo points out, even as we focus on productivity, we need to keep in mind that we should not pursue productivity as an end in itself.

 

     Er Lee Bee Wah asked about the relationship between productivity and wage growth.  We are pursuing productivity to raise value added per worker, because this ultimately determines whether our workers can receive higher wages.  Higher productivity enables us to generate the additional value that then can be shared between companies and workers, provide good jobs and higher

Column: 2734

incomes for workers and generate higher profits for companies.

 

 

 

     Ultimately, productivity is the basis for our future economic competitiveness.  I would like to reassure Mr Heng Chee How, Dr Lim Wee Kiak and Mr Laurence Wee that we are not about to let the pursuit of productivity blindside us to the over-arching objective of inclusive growth.  Even as we move forward in this productivity drive, we must provide the support for all, including and especially the lower-skilled and the older workers to move together with us in this journey.

 

     Our existing skill upgrading and training programmes, especially those at e2i, are targeted at precisely these workers, and in our review of the continuing education framework, we will continue to see how to assist these workers upgrade themselves. Several members, such as Mr Liang Eng Hwa, Ms Jessica Tan, Mr Sin Boon Ann, Mr Michael Palmer, Mr Calvin Cheng and Er Lee Bee Wah, have highlighted concerns regarding the impact on the foreign worker levy changes and its impact on businesses and living costs.  The Minister for Manpower will address this issue in greater detail in the debate on the Manpower Ministry's estimates. 

 

     Enterprises must take the lead in this next phase of our productivity efforts. Enterprises, ultimately, make the decision about what value they want to create and how they would go about doing so.  While workers can upskill themselves, the systems, processes and technology that they work within, sets the context within which they can apply these skills to generate higher value and these are put in place by the enterprise.  Likewise, workers can offer suggestions about new products or markets to expand into, but enterprises must have in place a culture and a system that can nurture and harness such creativity.

We have many progressive enterprises that have already taken the initiative to improve their productivity. Over the past week, Members have read many examples in the newspapers of companies, both here and abroad, that have done well on the productivity front and created better and more rewarding jobs for their workers.  So it can be done and we hope that through their exemplary conduct and practice that other companies and other CEOs and leaders will follow them and do so as well.  We need more enterprises to do the same.  I would like to highlight three examples here just to add to the list. 

 

     Hyflux's story is one of generating value by growing the top line through constant innovation to come up with new products and new uses for their products, and internationalisation to capture opportunities in new markets beyond Singapore.  Hyflux is a homegrown company that was founded just over 20 years ago with a start-up capital of $20,000 and just three staff.  Today, it is one of the world's fastest growing water solutions companies with $1.87 billion in market capitalisation.  At the heart of their business strategy is an innovation team responsible for the R&D of new products and applications and the commercialisation of technology.  They operate the largest commercial R&D centre for membranes and materials technology in Asia outside of Japan.  Today, Hyflux's products are installed in more than 1,000 plants in over 300 locations globally, providing water solutions in markets ranging from Southeast Asia, China, India, the Middle East and North Africa.  So that was improving the top line. 

 

     I will highlight another example from an SME again. This time, in process innovation.  Mr Sam Ho is the Managing Director of Vac-Tech Engineering. It is a local, industrial cleaning and environmental company.  Mr Ho is passionate about innovation and he is constantly looking out for new and better ways to

Column: 2736

work smart.  For example, he had this idea that instead of removing waste sludge from the oil storage tanks manually, they could raise productivity by mechanising the process.  He hired a consultant to help design the automated conveyor system and bring the concept to realisation.  With this innovation in place, they are now able to complete the job four times faster.  Mr Ho has also put in place a pay structure that rewards learning and upgrading among his workers.  So a sharing of the gains.  For example, those working as drivers are able to get an increment when they learn to operate the machines and double up as machine operators when necessary. 

 

     There is also great potential for productivity improvements at the cluster level. So it is not just individual companies or individual workers but at a cluster level. A good example of a cluster level project is when the Container Depot Association of Singapore, Singapore Logistics Association and Singapore Transport Association came together to undertake a project to set up a computerised tracking system for containers and prime movers.  Before the system was in place, prime movers brought containers in but came out empty-handed or they went in empty to bring out containers.  This new system enabled trucking companies to share their prime movers – going in and out of the port, minimise the number of empty trips, optimise the use of the prime movers and reduce the congestion in the port. It looks like an obvious solution but it requires companies in the sector to come together, to work together in order to make it happen.  At last count, more than 1,400 prime movers from 66 companies have benefited from the new system. 

 

      There are three broader points that I want to draw from these examples which will inform the Council's approach. First, there is no one-size-fits-all solution, as Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed noted.  The context for each enterprise and sector may differ

Column: 2737

significantly and require different customised strategies.  Second, to achieve sustained improvements, strategies and solutions must be integrated and supported by a culture of constant innovation and improvement. And I agree with Assoc. Prof. Koo that we have to look at productivity improvements on a system-wide level.  There is no point in investing in new technology, for example, if you do not train up your workforce to exploit it at the same time.  And as several Members have pointed out, there is no point in sending workers for training if they come back and the company continues to work in the same way as before and the training just goes to waste.  It is about applying creativity and imagination to improve even the smallest thing that you do.  Third, as Mr Zaqy Mohamad shared, this effort can be sustained only if we see enterprises gaining from higher efficiency and effectiveness and workers gaining from higher skills and higher wages.  In short, our productivity drive will require concerted tripartite effort involving enterprises, workers and the Government.

 

     Enterprises must take the lead to invest in improving processes, like Vac-Tech Engineering, enhancing the value of their products, like Hyflux, and across sectors like our container trucking industry.  Workers, with the support of our unions, must take ownership for upgrading. They must want to upgrade themselves. The public sector too must play its part to be more productive and innovative in itself, across the whole of Government, as well as to facilitate the National Productivity drive. And in this, I agree with Members, including Ms Jessica Tan, Ms Ellen Lee, Mr Seah Kian Peng and Er Lee Bee Wah, and the public sector will do its part. Overall, the Government is not in a position to pick and choose winners and neither do we have all the answers but we can certainly help those who want

Column: 2738

to help themselves.  Bring all the parties together and do the facilitation. 

 

     The Government, working with companies and workers through the Council, will facilitate the transition from the current level to the next level of productivity in a company or a sector.  To enable broad-based and sustained improvements in productivity, we need to go beyond driving productivity.  As many MPs have pointed out, we need to nurture a productivity culture.  It is about building productivity into a deeply ingrained mindset that permeates the entire business process and model and the workers' outlook and the whole nation.  We will have to build capability and develop tools to help both employers and workers at all levels to constantly look for opportunities for productivity improvement.  This means that we will need to train them on productivity-related skills in addition to job-related skills.  The Council will have various tools and schemes that it will use in driving the productivity movement.

 

     Enterprises can already leverage on the suite of capability development programmes at SPRING – be it technology improvements, human resource capabilities or even design and branding. SPRING will work together with enterprises to assess their needs and support them in addressing these capability gaps in an integrated and holistic manner. We will see how SPRING can streamline its processes in order to make the various schemes more accessible to SMEs in particular.  Enterprises can also draw on centres of innovation at our polytechnics and research institutes for technology consultancy and advice.  I am keen for the Council to study how our companies, especially our SMEs, can work more closely, in particular with our polytechnics and ITEs but also with our universities to come up with product and process innovations and associated worker training. 

 

    

Column: 2739

The Minister for Finance has announced an additional boost in the form of the productivity and innovation credit.  In the past, companies have felt that only those who are involved in the very high tech esoteric sectors can benefit from schemes to encourage R&D and capital investments.  The small and medium enterprises also felt that only big companies can qualify for such benefits and schemes. 

 

     The new Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) is different, in that it is a broad-based scheme that is open to all enterprises across all sectors.  It does not merely cover investments in equipment to automate processes.  It also incentivises investments and innovation, such as R&D, design and acquisition of intellectual property such as patents and trademarks, to revamp its processes, products or business model.  So businesses which invest in making themselves more productive and innovative will get to enjoy an unprecedented 250% tax deduction benefit of up to $300,000 per activity.  The PIC is capped at $300,000 for each approved activity.  So the benefits accrue mainly to SMEs.  Also, recognising the SMEs often are cash-tight or have not yet generated sufficient profits to benefit fully from a tax credit, the PIC can be converted to a cash grant of up to $21,000.  Beyond this broad-based approach, the Council will focus on selected sectors that employ a significant proportion of the workforce and have the most potential for productivity improvements. This is to ensure that our efforts make the greatest impact at the outset.  One sector clearly is construction. We have spoken about that a lot these last two days.  The sector has great potential for productivity increases and also employs many workers, including foreign workers, but we will look at other sectors as well, and other key sectors we will look at include retail, food and beverage, hospitality, transport and logistics, general

Column: 2740

manufacturing, precision engineering and business services industries. 

 

     Mrs Josephine Teo highlighted the need to go beyond the broad 2%-3% productivity target, and Mr Teo Siong Seng also said that the Council needed to have an understanding of what is happening on the ground for effective implementation. So to facilitate this, the Council will take a sector-specific approach. The Council will identify Government agencies that will work with industry partners, such as business associations and/or the more progressive leading companies and industries and, of course, the unions in that sector, to develop strategies and solutions to raise productivity in their respective sectors. Together, they will study the nature of their sector, develop customised productivity strategies and propose new initiatives to complement existing ones, especially to complement the broad-based ones.  I will illustrate an example of how this could be done. 

 

     NParks has been working on the productivity issue since 2007. They began by conducting a five-month labour productivity benchmark study for seven landscaping companies and developed a matrix of performance and process indicators customised for the landscaping industry. So we have taken a broad productivity indicator and tried to customise it to something that is meaningful for that sector and the companies in that sector. This was accompanied by a work trip to Australia to learn more about best practices in productivity in the landscaping industry. The study not only allowed companies to gain awareness of how their own productivity compared with group average, it also gave them insights on implementing new projects to improve their companies' management and work processes.

 

 

NParks also obtained a clearer understanding of the productivity gaps within the industry and NParks is now

Column: 2741

working with the industry on other initiatives to bring their capabilities and productivity to another level.  For example, they are conducting an analysis of the value chain to identify room for synergies, developing a training framework for the industry and conducting industry dialogue sessions to bring industry players on board for benchmarking initiative and to share and promote best practices. 

 

     To support the national productivity drive, the Minister for Finance announced the setting up of a $2 billion National Productivity Fund to complement existing industry development programmes.  Agencies like NParks can come to the Council to seek funding for their sectoral initiatives.  Business associations can also take the initiatives and work with their members in coming up with sectoral strategies and initiatives for the Council to consider.  The Council will also review existing programmes and consider introducing new ones to support sector-specific strategies.  The Council will also direct funds towards developing infrastructure and tools that enterprises can use to support their productivity efforts.  These will include setting up sector-focused resource centres to do applied research into productivity, identify international best practices and develop productivity benchmarks. 

 

     Over the past few decades, we have built up a world-class education system starting with mass basic education through the 1960s and 1970s in primary and secondary schools to high-quality mass further and higher education from the 1980s onwards, including our network of ITEs, polytechnics and universities.  The vast majority of our students today come through a solid basic education and go through further and higher education. 

 

     We are now embarking on a similar journey in building our continuing

Column: 2742

education and training system to give our adult workers a comprehensive slate of opportunities to develop their potential, raise their competitiveness and spur their mobility throughout their working lives.  This is a key prong of our strategy.  As highlighted by Mr Yeo Guat Kwang, we can enable workers to be more productive only if we provide the training and the systems for them to be trained to do so.

 

     The Council will oversee the development of a world-class national CET system that caters to everyone and is customised to the needs of different workers and companies.  This includes the older, low-wage worker who wants to gain basic literacy and numeracy skills, a technician who is mastering new areas of technology, an executive who is looking to develop cross-functional skills and the professional acquiring specialised expertise in his field.  The Council will identify and develop new focus areas of growth for the CET system in line with the skills needed to support the productivity drive.  We have a variety of training providers and qualification systems today.  We must leverage on this diversity; yet, also build stronger linkages between different qualifications and institutions.  We will study models from various countries and learn from their best elements, at the same time, retaining the strong linkage between our CET and economic strategies that has always been a hallmark of our system. 

 

     Ultimately, developing a world-class CET system is not just about putting in more resources or setting up more institutions or programmes.  What drives the success of CET is whether our employers and workers have a strong culture of life-long learning.  The Government can develop the system but employers must recognise that investing in their people is a key competitive advantage for their business.  And workers need to keep an open mind about different job opportunities and must have the desire to

Column: 2743

improve their skills to meet new trends at work. 

 

     Training must be a way of life, not a burden nor an imposition.  Lifelong learning is a means to an end and that end is to add value.  The ability to add value will bring about better employability and better income for workers.  In this regard, we can learn from the Scandinavian countries where CET is a long established tradition and there is a very strong culture of lifelong learning.  In 2007, about a third (32%) of the workforce in Singapore underwent training.  Not bad.  But when compared with Denmark when nearly half (45%) of the workforce underwent training, we have some way to go.  And 45% need not be our ultimate target either.  In Denmark, they also have a high degree of job mobility, whether it is to take on jobs that require more or higher skills in the same or a different field. 

 

     As our enterprises and sectors move towards higher productivity, the skill-sets and skill levels of our workers will need to move up in tandem.  Developing this world-class CET system will help our workers create greater value in their current companies and enable them to cross over into new, higher value work areas and industries as these come on stream in Singapore.  Already many of our workers and companies recognise the value of CET in increasing their mobility and have benefited from it.  Let me illustrate with three examples. 

 

     The first shows how a company's strong culture and support for training has enabled its workers to move up the ranks.  Thirty-one year old Mr Gerald Tan started working as a driver at Toh Kim Bock CE Contractor Pte Ltd in 2001, earning $1,300 a month.  He was promoted to foreman two years later with his good work attitude.  Recognising his interest and talent for landscaping, his company sent him for WSQ landscaping courses with the Centre for Urban Greenery and

Column: 2744

Ecology and a safety supervisor course with BCA Academy.  He got another promotion, becoming a landscape supervisor in 2006, earning $2,000 a month.  In 2009, Mr Tan completed the International Society of Arboriculture's certified arborist programme and is now a certified arborist who supervises 30 workers from five sites.  He now earns $2,600, twice his starting salary several years ago. 

 

     Second, is a lady who has made a mid-career switch after CET.  Miss Siaw Ruifan, 25, graduated with a diploma in chemical engineering from a local polytechnic and was working as a sales coordinator in an export company.  In 2006, she took up a professional conversion programme for registered nurses – a two-year nursing diploma course.  She is now working as a nurse in SGH, and I am pleased to learn that she finds the job helping patients a very rewarding one.

 

     The third is a professional who has made a diagonal move, across and up through CET.  The first was moving vertically in the same company, the second was moving horizontally.  Miss Fatimah Moideen Kutty rose through the ranks to become Head of Pharmacy from 2000 to 2008.  With establishment of the new Khoo Teck Puat Hospital, she was asked to help drive the transition as a Deputy Director of  Human Resources.  She took the WSQ Chief People Officer programme at Human Capital (Singapore).  The training has equipped her with the HR skills to progress and succeed in a new role. 

 

     We need to work together to make the productivity drive a sustained effort at every level.  We will face challenges but there are also plenty of opportunities.  Each sector, each enterprise and each individual must take collective responsibility for sustaining productivity efforts and proactively take the initiative to

Column: 2745

improve in their respective spheres.  I have confidence that Singapore will rise up to meet the challenge as we have always done.  The strength of our unique tripartite partnership will be a critical success factor as we continue on this journey. 

 

     In other countries, the call to raise productivity and transform the workplace may have caused unions to rise up in alarm, but our unions are different.  We have risen up already.  They have taken it upon themselves to lead the labour movement in meeting this productivity challenge.  They know that this is for the long term good of our workers; in fact, they have already started work.

 

     Minister Lim Swee Say, Secretary-General of NTUC, is leading the "Cheaper, Better, Faster" movement to rally the unions and the workers behind this national productivity drive.  We have heard Mdm Halimah Yacob, Mrs Josephine Teo, Mr Yeo Guat Kwang and other of our labour MPs, speaking passionately about this in this House.  I would like to commend their efforts and encourage them to continue in this effort as we need to bring everyone on board, and the workers especially.

 

     There is no easy road to success.  This is an effort for the long haul.  Results will not come in months or even within the year but, through this journey, we will build a resilient economy that will give us sustained inclusive growth, nurture highly competitive sectors and enterprises and workers who take pride in maximising their potential through a passion for lifelong learning and upgrading.  Working together steadily, steadfastly and, in a practical way, drawing on the collective knowledge and energy of all our partners, we will be able to achieve our goals and build a better future for Singapore and Singaporeans.      Assoc. Prof. Paulin Tay Straughan (Nominated Member): Thank you, Sir, for this opportunity to share my views.

 

     The key thrust of Budget 2010 is to build up capabilities needed to transform the Singapore economy over the next 10 years.  Fundamentally, the message is:  we need to level up on productivity for each worker as we learn to maximise the potential from every available Singaporean while we wean ourselves from the dependency on surplus foreign labour.

 

     As a family sociologist, I am acutely aware that while the Budget highlights the issues of a limited and fast-ageing workforce, it does not address directly the root cause of this predicament and that is sustained ultra-low fertility and delayed marriages among younger Singaporeans.


     When the economy performs poorly, as it has done in the past year, the effects are easily quantifiable through indicators like the negative GDP, budget deficit and unemployment statistics.  The reaction from state is also swift and focused – as detailed in the recommendations of the Economic Strategies Committee (ESC) and the subsequent endorsement of the ESC’s key thrusts in Budget 2010.  But as a nation, we must be cognisant that the Singapore family may also be in crisis.  The key indicators of this are clearly illustrated in population trends:  increase in age at first marriage,  sustained ultra-low fertility, increase in the proportion of singles and a fast ageing population.  While these indicators may not be measured in fiscal terms, the consequences on the sustainability of Singapore society is just as critical.

5.28 pm     

 

     If we had not opened our doors to contributions from our foreign friends, the

Column: 2747

Singapore population would have shrunk – just as it has in Japan and South Korea.  But augmenting our numbers through immigration has also resulted in social tensions, which has dominated much of the discourse in both the print and new media in the past year.  So now, we have decided that we need to slow down the inflow of foreigners and learn to level up on productivity of the workers we have.

     In my own research on the Singapore family, a key barrier to early marriage and having children that surfaced is the perceived lack of time. 

 

 

It takes time – to find the right life partner, to learn how to love, and to nurture children.  It seems that Singaporeans have very little time, especially our younger Singaporeans. Why is that so?


    Singaporeans work very hard. I looked at the Singapore Yearbook of manpower statistics published in 2009.  On average, we clocked 47.1 hours per week in 2008, and these are paid hours.  The hours registered in construction, manufacturing

Column: 2748

and administration and support services were the highest – 52.5 per week; 50.4 per week and 49.7 per week respectively.  So what does this translate to in real terms?  On average, we clock nine hours of paid work. There are 24 hours in a day. So nine hours, we take away two hours for transportation, that is 11 hours.  We take away another two hours for basic necessities – nutrition, cleaning, personal grooming, etc – and that would be 13 hours.  Let us say that we sleep eight hours, as prescribed by the physicians, you add that up together, that is 21 hours. That leaves us a miserable three hours to find your soul mate, to nurture relationship, to procreate and to nurse the baby.  The average number of hours we work is higher than that of many other nations, including Japan and South Korea.  So this call for productivity.  To work smarter is indeed timely because I look forward to when we can increase productivity so that Singaporean workers can cut back on paid work so that they can focus on family which is just as important.


    Madam, my main concerns on Budget 2010 relate to the implications on how we do family in Singapore.  Broadly, they cover two key areas: how we can achieve a  sensible work-life balance and the place of family in our value system.

 

    I will address concerns relating to achieving a sensible work-life balance first.


    As we heed the call to improve productivity at the workplace, across all sectors, how can we ensure that productivity is understood and measured accurately, especially in service industries and where cognitive processes are involved?  I think that is rather tricky.

 

    Will middle-managers and supervisors be sufficiently trained themselves to recognise quality output of their supervisees?  I think all of us in this House

Column: 2749

agree that, in principle, the ideology set out in the Budget and the ESC Report is sound and we stand solidly by it.  I think the trick now is how do we operationalise it so that it filters down accurately through the workforce.

 

    How will training programmes be validated?  We certainly do not want to send our workers to training for the sake of fulfilling the call to train. We must be able to validate that every training session adds value to the way we do our work.  How will we ensure that this call to work smarter will not be operationalised as working longer hours by ignorant managers?  This, I think, we have to really seriously watch.  The Singapore worker is already clocking maximum hours at work. The only way we can be more productive is if employers are willing to invest in training and infrastructure. 

 

     But when push comes to shove, employers may resort to squeezing even more out of each worker without first investing in improving their skills.  I am especially concerned for those employed in smaller enterprises which are highly dependent currently on foreign workers. Will they be able to downsize their labour force and concurrently upgrade existing labour while watching closely their profit margin?


     What is the recourse for employees when demands from the workplace clearly disadvantage them and make it difficult for them to carry out their responsibilities in their families?


    In these challenging and exciting times of transformation at the workplace, may I suggest that we track work hours systematically and that we track informal overtime work as well because I think this is the culprit that locks us in the office.

 

    One key thrust recommendation of the ESC is to make Singapore an attractive

Column: 2750

global city and an endearing home.  We can only be such a city if we have a good work-life balance in our everyday life.


    We must recognise that Singaporeans may have varying social obligations in the family, and in this climate where work demands dominate, I will appreciate assurance from the Minister that there is a place for supplementary wage earners in a transformed economy. 

 

    Mature workers and workers with care-giving responsibilities may be able to only work part-time.  With an ageing population, this pool of workers will likely increase.  We must ensure that these Singaporeans are not perceived of as liabilities in the workplace and that part-time workers continue to receive opportunities to upgrade their skills, receive a fair wage for their labour and sufficient benefits in kind.


    One way to facilitate a satisfactory marrying of paid work and home work is to allow employees the flexibility in where and when they can conduct their work. Wherever possible, we should encourage organisations to embrace a flexi-schedule and make flexi-work options available. 

 

    My second concern, Madam, relates to how we position the family in Singapore.  In all that we do, we must reiterate the importance of family.      The Budget is a powerful  ideological statement. It sends strong messages of what constitutes core concerns for our nation.  I would like to see noted in a progressive Budget the sacredness of family time, and how family time must never be treated irreverently as surplus work time. Every time we expect our workers to stay beyond office hours, we must be mindful that there is a gap in his or her family.

 

     We must accord due respect to family work, especially the important work of care givers.  We must, as a nation, set the norms that support Singaporeans who

Column: 2751

embrace the social and moral responsibility to care for their family members. One way we can do this to provide time-off from work for Singaporeans to take care of their dependants.  We have in place childcare leave for parents of young children. As our population ages, I believe that it is timely that we should broaden that to include leave for eldercare.  While ensuring a sustained level of productivity in the economy is important, it is equally important, if not more important, that we uphold productivity in the family.  Family time is not surplus work time.  It is time to nurture marital bonds and inter-generational relationships.

     Comparing the unemployment rate of male residents between 2008 and 2009 showed that the men with lower education, aged between 30 and 39 years are more vulnerable to unemployment.  The unemployment rates of men in this age group with primary education and below rose by 4.7 percentage points between 2008 and 2009.  That means the unemployment rate for this group was 4.0% to 8.7% in 2009.  The percentage point increase for men aged 40 to 49 years old with the same educational level was much lower, only 0.5 percentage point increase from 4.9% to 5.4%.

Column: 2762

     Although the question is on the National Electronic Health Record (NEHR) currently being implemented, I will briefly provide the backdrop to this development so that NEHR is seen in its proper context.

     The clusters had developed their EMRs independently.  This created a problem when a patient moved across the cluster.  As an interim solution, we implemented an Electronic Medical Records Exchange (EMRX) to allow secure cross-cluster exchange of patient information so that regardless of where the patient seeks treatment, key information could be pulled to enable safer decision making. Subsequently, we extended EMRX to some healthcare partners.  Today, the EMRX is a pivotal capability that allows easy movement of records across the public healthcare clusters, community hospitals and MINDEF, facilitating care delivery.

 

     All these efforts have shown the early benefits in safety and convenience for our patients as information is much more easily accessed at various points of care.  However, the current EMRX has a major drawback:  it is essentially a document-level exchange, with no standardised or structured data.  While it has been useful, it limits further exploitation of the data.  Seamless sharing of data beyond documents is very difficult, if not impossible.  For example, diagnostic images, including X-rays, cannot be exchanged over the EMRX, because various institutions use different vendors and their current viewers use different versions of image protocols. Images from one institution are therefore not easily readable in another institution without degradation of quality and significant translation effort. 

 

     The lack of structured data also means that anything beyond information exchange, such as making the system "smarter" to aid clinical decisions, research and disease surveillance is technically impossible.


    

Column: 2791

Recent progress in IT and further standardisation of medical data internationally has enabled us now to move into the next step of IT exploitation.  In particular, as healthcare systems seek to integrate service delivery beyond acute hospitals to include the providers in the community in order to right-site services, raise the level of chronic disease management and empower patients to look after their health proactively, the need for a National Electronic Health Record system has been recognised here and in many developed countries.  This is a necessary step forward to create a health record that is truly personalised and available everywhere. 

 

     Unlike some other countries, we are not starting from scratch.  We are building on the strong foundations of the past investments in healthcare IT that our public hospitals already have in place today.  The NEHR is not to replace EMRs.  Indeed, we will need to continue to invest in the EMRs at the clusters level to further exploit IT within the institutions.  The level of details required in a local EMR is much more than in a NEHR.  The NEHR will ride on the EMRs, drawing key information from the various EMRs in the public healthcare institutions, in order to construct a patient-centric view for both healthcare workers and patients to make better care decisions. Thus, the NEHR sets out the system-level architecture for how the different existing and new systems must fit together. To make this possible, we have to settle the standards for the data and establish the ways to properly exchange and synchronise information over a longitudinal basis.  Moreover, in order to support integration of care and chronic disease management, NEHR has to cover the entire healthcare ecosystem, and not just the public sector.

 

     This is therefore a complex and difficult undertaking.  Full implementation will take many years.  We are proceeding in phases so that each subsequent phase will take into account the experience of the earlier phase and be able to exploit emerging technologies. We may not need to extend the NEHR to every healthcare provider. Each phase of new incremental investment will have to be justified on cost-benefit grounds.  We have a long term goal but we are not committing to the details of each subsequent phase.  Put it another way, we have set the direction that we are going, but we are not committing to the pace of reaching each subsequent milestone.  We will settle such details incrementally and progressively.  This is a prudent way going forward, as IT will continue to evolve.
